item.title: analytics tools for the minimal web

description.p: so for my most recent design and development projects, i have been using two tools that i have come to deeply adore: piratepx and counter.dev

these two tools, for me (with very small and simple projects to put out) at least, these analytics tracking tools are perfect. they do not use much of the users bandwidth or compute time trying to download a bunch of tracking javascript or adding cookies to the browser.

due to both being highly privacy focused, they dont have the need to create cookies, fingerprint ip addresses, log extensive user data, etc. counter.dev costs the user about 730 bytes whereas piratepx asks for only 37 bytes.

piratepx can be sooo lightweight since it only ships a 1x1 pixel .gif file to the user which then counts as a pageview. counter.dev provides a bit more insight about the user's device, country, traffic source, etc while still having the same privacy features.

honestly love both of them and i've used pirate px for adithya.zip for a long time as then i would only need to see a count of the people visiting the website and didnt need any unneeded info such as the devices, country, sources, etc of the visitors. however now i use counter.dev for this since adding the blog so that i can see from where people find my webpage from so that i can try to increase traffic. for my other products however, moment, neutral and newtab, i have always used counter.dev, as i need a bit more insight on where my users are coming from and how they access the website / product. honestly these two are the best tools to use if you dont want to use google analytics or dont want to pay for plausible analytics.
